questions.text: Which of the following types of microorganisms is photosynthetic?
questions.explanation: Algae are eukaryotic microorganisms that contain chloroplasts and perform photosynthesis. Yeasts are fungi, viruses are acellular, and helminths are parasitic worms.

questions.text: Which type of microscope would be the best choice for viewing very small surface structures of a cell?
questions.explanation: Scanning electron microscopes (SEMs) are designed to visualize surface details at high resolution. Transmission electron microscopes (TEMs) view internal structures.

questions.text: Which type of cytoskeletal fiber is important in the formation of the nuclear lamina?
questions.explanation: Intermediate filaments, specifically lamins, form the nuclear lamina, providing structural support to the nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following bacterial species is classified as high G+C gram-positive?
questions.explanation: Corynebacterium species are characterized as high G+C Gram-positive bacteria. Bacillus, Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus are low G+C Gram-positives.

questions.text: A fluke is classified within which of the following?
questions.explanation: Flukes (trematodes) are parasitic flatworms belonging to the phylum Platyhelminthes.

questions.text: A non-segmented worm is found during a routine colonoscopy of an individual who reported having abdominal cramps, nausea, and vomiting. This worm is likely which of the following?
questions.explanation: Nematodes (roundworms) are non-segmented. Flukes (trematodes) are flatworms. Annelids are segmented worms.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics/compounds is not considered to be a phenotypic biochemical characteristic used of microbial identification?
questions.explanation: The 16S rRNA gene sequence is a genotypic characteristic used for identification, not a phenotypic biochemical test result.

questions.text: In prokaryotes, in which direction are hydrogen ions pumped by the electron transport system of photosynthetic membranes?
options: to the inside (cytoplasm) of the cell
to the intermembrane space of the chloroplast
to the outside of the plasma membrane
questions.answer: to the outside of the plasma membrane
questions.explanation: In prokaryotic photosynthesis, protons are pumped from the cytoplasm across the plasma membrane to the exterior, generating a proton motive force.

questions.text: Which of the following are two products of the light-dependent reactions?
questions.explanation: The light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis convert light energy into chemical energy in the form of ATP and NADPH.

questions.text: Which of the following is the group of archaea that can use CO2 as their final electron acceptor during anaerobic respiration, producing CH4?
questions.explanation: Methanogens are archaea that produce methane (CH4) by using CO2 as a terminal electron acceptor in anaerobic respiration.

questions.text: In which environment are you most likely to encounter a hyperthermophile?
options: hydrothermal vent at the bottom of the ocean
questions.answer: hydrothermal vent at the bottom of the ocean
questions.explanation: Hyperthermophiles thrive in extremely hot environments, such as deep-sea hydrothermal vents where temperatures can be well above boiling point at surface pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following environments would harbor psychrophiles?
options: contaminated plates left in a 35 °C incubator
mountain lake with a water temperature of 12 °C
salt pond in the desert with a daytime temperature of 34 °C
questions.answer: mountain lake with a water temperature of 12 °C
questions.explanation: Psychrophiles are cold-loving organisms that grow optimally at 15°C or lower. A mountain lake at 12°C is a suitable environment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason jams and dried meats often do not require refrigeration to prevent spoilage?
questions.explanation: Low water activity (aw) in jams (due to high sugar) and dried meats (due to desiccation) limits available water for microbial growth, thus preserving them.

questions.text: Serratia marcescens cells produce a red pigment at room temperature. The red color of the colonies is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Phenotype refers to the observable characteristics of an organism, such as pigment production, resulting from its genotype and environmental interactions.

questions.text: Bleach is an example of which group of chemicals used for disinfection?
questions.explanation: Bleach (sodium hypochlorite) is a chlorine-based compound, and chlorine is a halogen. Halogens are effective disinfectants.

questions.text: Which chemical disinfectant works by methylating enzymes and nucleic acids and is known for being toxic and carcinogenic?
questions.explanation: Formaldehyde is an alkylating agent that methylates proteins and nucleic acids, making it a potent disinfectant but also toxic and carcinogenic.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques cannot be used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug against a particular microbe?
questions.explanation: The Kirby-Bauer test determines susceptibility (susceptible, intermediate, resistant) but does not directly yield an MIC value. Broth dilution and Etest determine MIC.

questions.text: The utility of an antibiogram is that it shows antimicrobial susceptibility trends
questions.explanation: Antibiograms summarize susceptibility data for a specific healthcare facility or region, helping to guide empirical therapy and monitor local resistance patterns.

questions.text: Which of the following has yielded compounds with the most antimicrobial activity?
questions.explanation: Soil is a rich source of diverse microorganisms, many of which produce antibiotics as secondary metabolites, leading to numerous antimicrobial drug discoveries.

questions.text: Which of the following types of drug-resistant bacteria do not typically persist in individuals as a member of their intestinal microbiota?
questions.explanation: MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) primarily colonizes the skin and nares, while VRE, CRE, and ESBL-producing Enterobacteriaceae are more commonly associated with intestinal colonization.

questions.text: In the Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test, the _______ of the zone of inhibition is measured and used for interpretation.
questions.explanation: The diameter of the zone of inhibition (area of no growth) around an antibiotic disk in the Kirby-Bauer test is measured to assess susceptibility.

questions.text: Which of the following is a major virulence factor for the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus?
questions.explanation: The polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus species is a critical virulence factor that protects the fungus from host immune defenses, particularly phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogens undergoes antigenic variation to avoid immune defenses?
questions.explanation: Plasmodium, the parasite causing malaria, exhibits antigenic variation by changing its surface proteins, allowing it to evade the host's adaptive immune response.

questions.text: Bacteria are ________________ because their genetic material (DNA) is not housed within a true nucleus.
questions.explanation: Prokaryotic cells, like bacteria, lack a membrane-bound nucleus; their DNA is located in a nucleoid region.

questions.text: There are two basic types of preparation used to view specimens with a light microscope: wet mounts and _______________.
questions.explanation: Wet mounts are used for living organisms. Fixed specimens involve attaching organisms to a slide, usually followed by staining to enhance visibility.

questions.text: Organelles such as mitochondria, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and peroxisomes are held in place by the ______________, an internal network that supports transport of intracellular components and helps maintain cell shape.
questions.explanation: The cytoskeleton is a network of protein filaments within eukaryotic cells that provides structural support, facilitates intracellular transport, and maintains cell shape.

questions.text: __________________ is the primary stain of the Gram stain procedure.
questions.explanation: Crystal violet is the first stain applied in the Gram staining procedure, staining all bacterial cells purple initially.

questions.text: A lichen is a combination of two organisms, a green alga or cyanobacterium and ____________, living in a symbiotic relationship.
questions.explanation: Lichens are a mutualistic symbiosis between a fungus (mycobiont) and a photosynthetic partner, either an alga or a cyanobacterium (photobiont).

questions.text: Sugar groups may be added to proteins in which of the following?
questions.explanation: Glycosylation (adding sugar groups to proteins) begins in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and is further modified and completed in the Golgi apparatus.

questions.text: Which period is the stage of disease during which the patient begins to present general signs and symptoms?
questions.explanation: The prodromal period follows incubation and is characterized by the appearance of early, non-specific signs and symptoms of disease.

questions.text: Chitin cell walls are characteristic of the ______________ taxonomic group.
questions.explanation: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide that forms the primary component of fungal cell walls.

questions.text: During specimen preparation for transmission electron microscopy, the specimens are ______________ in alcohol and embedded in plastic resin.
questions.explanation: Specimens for TEM must be dehydrated, typically using a graded series of alcohol, to remove water before embedding in resin for sectioning.

questions.text: Name the term best describes the relationship between pathogenic bacteria and humans?
questions.explanation: Parasitism is a symbiotic relationship where one organism (the parasite, e.g., pathogenic bacteria) benefits at the expense of the host (humans).
